name: Pastel de Nata - Portuguese Custard Tarts

text.text: Pastel de Nata - Portuguese Custard Tarts

So back in the day (that's the 18th century) Portuguese convents and monasteries used to starch their nuns' habits and the like with egg whites. That's a lot of egg whites, and a whole lot of yolks, too. These needed using up, so all the good monks and all the good nuns swiftly turned them into delicious custard tarts. Clever sods.

They sprinkled a little cinnamon on for flavour, caramelised the tops and made a pretty penny selling them too. Now we know you get them any-old-where these days, but these spots make their own - so time it right and they'll be warm, gooey and fresh to death.

tip.text: Bopping along the bustling West Green Road is a hectic international blur, and Bom Pecado is Portugal's representative: a slightly scruffy spot serving up cakes, sandwiches, salads and freshly baked breads to locals looking to have a catch up and chill. No sign of laptops, exposed brickwork or bare bulbs - it's an authentic, old-school cafe where grizzly Portuguese geezers stand up at the cubby hole sipping on cervejas. If you're not in the boozing mood, stick to a cappuccino and a pastel de nata.

text.text: Tottenham's West Green Road is a hectic international blur, and Bom Pecado is Portugal's representative: a slightly scruffy spot serving up cakes, sandwiches, salads and freshly baked breads to locals looking to have a catch up and chill. No sign of laptops or exposed brickwork - it's an authentic, old-school cafe where grizzly Portuguese geezers sip on cervejas.

tip.text: We love this spot not just for the cheap coffee served in iconic tall glasses in little plastic cages; nor for the crisp natas with beautifully spiced custard that has only just set; nor for the shaded outside tables perfect for people watching. The real draw here is the palpable sense of energy in the room: older Portuguese women having a natter with their nata, the hiss of the coffee machine and the barks of the servers all becoming a rolling laid-back buzz that consumes and comforts you all at once. Itâ€™s very popular amongst locals, so you may have to wait for a seat - but once one becomes available feel free to plonk it down at any table outside and youâ€™ll be greeted with smiles and nods in true continental fashion.

text.text: Locals know best, and most W10 natives will concur that despite its unglamorous appearance, Lisboa Patisserie is the place for a coffee and cake. Itâ€™s hard to miss the strong Portuguese influence on the Golborne road, so listen closely and follow the accents to this gem. And when you're there? Natas!

tip.text:
What initially started out as a little shop on Columbia Rd selling Portuguese curios and foodstuffs has now turned into a cute little deli-cafÃ© on Hackney Rd. The good folks behind A Portuguese Love Affair serve up warm and welcoming Mediterranean vibes and some of the best pastÃ©is de nata (custard tarts) we've had this side of the ocean.

All sorts of Portuguese goodies are available to have in or take-away - wines, cheeses, cured meats, tinned fish, toasties, salads and pastries. Weekend specials include the ultimate summery comfort food: bacalhau Ã  brÃ¡s, made from salt cod, eggs, fried potato matchsticks, olives and coriander - the perfect excuse to order a crisp glass of Portuguese white, or two.

text.text: What initially started out as a little shop on Columbia Road selling Portuguese curios and foodstuffs has now turned into a cute little deli/cafÃ© on Hackney Road. All sorts of Portuguese goodies are available to have in or take-away - wines, cheeses, cured meats, tinned fish, toasties, salads, pastries and you know whats.

tip.text:
This real-deal Portuguese deli, cafe and restaurant imports all of its ingredients directly from... yep... Portugal. Its smart modern decor lends an upmarket feel that brings in some medium fancy Covent Garden folk. They might pop in for a breakfast of strong coffee with pastries, scrambled eggs and chorizo or pastel de nata; a lunch of tuna salads or jamon sandwiches; or a dinner of piri piri chicken, catch of the day or the renowned bacalhau (salt cod) with potatoes and eggs.

Thing is the small-plates game can be a bit spenny, so we'd just swing by for a glass of vinho verde and a little snack - Canela is as lovely a place as any to drink wine in.

text.text: This real-deal Portugese deli/cafe/restaurant imports all of its ingredients directly from the homeland. Pop in for homemade breads and cured meats at lunch or check it out after dark when it turns into a proper restaurant. We had the Bacalhau Bras (no idea how to pronounce that) and a little wine with our nata.

tip.text:
The lovely people who own this space beneath the arches in Vauxhall are covering all bases: there's a family-run restaurant serving up home-cooked Portuguese; a well stocked deli full of Iberian goodness, a bar and a vibrant cafe doing coffee and cakes. And by cakes, you know we're talking natas: those delicious creamy bites of custard goodness - which you can physically never eat too many of, according to science.

This place just feels authentic, from the distinctive red Sagres seats and parasols outside to the numerous locals whiling away their weekends with a coffee, beer or some of that home-cooked grub. The food is really nothing special but this is a lively enough spot to spend some time - our tip would be to grab a coffee and some of those natas.

text.text: Casa Madeira encompasses a family-run restaurant; a well stocked deli full of Iberian goodness, a bar and a vibrant cafe doing coffee and cakes. And by cakes, you know we're talking natas. From the distinctive red Sagres seats and parasols outside to the numerous locals whiling away their weekends - this place feels real authentic.

tip.text: Family and business don't always mix (just ask the Gallaghers) but at Anderson & Co, mother and daughter are working in harmony to bring a dope cafe-brasserie to the streets of Peckham. This place is the master of all trades: breakfast and brunch served til 3pm, award-winning sarnies and a sexy and dinner menu full of fine fare and veggie deliciousness. Our brekkie selection was the French toast and cinnamon sugar served with Turkish yoghurt and fresh berries. A chilled neighbourhood spot to call your new local.

text.text: Family and business don't always mix (just ask the Gallaghers) but at Anderson & Co, mother and daughter are working in harmony to bring a dope cafe-brasserie to the streets of Peckham. This place is the master of all trades: dinner, lunch, breakfast, brunch and homemade fresh bakes.

tip.text:
The clever folks at Wild Goose Bakery know exactly what theyâ€™re doing. They do all this baking and then stack it up in piles in the window. We walked past, a little pool of saliva formed in our mouths, next thing weâ€™re handing over hard earned cash in exchange for pastel de nata, still warm from the oven. Those little tartlets of flaky pastry filled with custard, caramelised and cinnamony touched us in places no-one had in a while.

Pretty much all of the produce is locally sourced, including coffee beans from local roasters Climpson & Sons and sodas from Hackneyâ€™s Square Root London. Loose leaf tea is from Scotland - thatâ€™s ok right? If youâ€™re foolish enough to be avoiding cinnamon swirls, bake-wells, muffins, flapjacks, brownies, lemon drizzle and the like then weâ€™ll allow you a soup, quiche or sarnieâ€¦ but weâ€™re watching you.

text.text: The clever folks at Wild Goose Bakery know exactly what theyâ€™re doing - baking cinnamon swirls, bake-wells, muffins, flapjacks, brownies, lemon drizzle and pastel de nata. We copped one. Still warm from the oven, the flaky pastry filled with custard, caramelised and cinnamony, touched us in places no one had in a while.

tip.text: It feels like everyone and their mum went to Lisbon on holiday this year but if you're not included in that mass generalisation, you can still experience the Portuguese way of life at this tavern tucked away in one of the arches of Flat Iron Square. Bar Douro is inspired by the traditional tascas of Portugal and is serving up small dishes like croquettes de alheira, LeitÃ£o suckling pig and Cataplana fish stew. Pastel de nata with cinnamon ice cream and Portuguese cheeses are on the dessert menu and Portuguese wine should help the holiday feels flow.

text.text: This tavern tucked away in one of the arches of Flat Iron Square, does Portuguese fare with flair. Inspired by the traditional tascas of Portugal, Bar Douro serves up small dishes like croquettes de alheira, LeitÃ£o suckling pig and Cataplana fish stew. And their pastel de nata come with cinnamon ice cream - slurp slurp.
